session.topic: Ways to improve and build upon the deliberation room

messages.text: Deliberation started: "Ways to improve and build upon the deliberation room"

Deliberation open. Topic: ways to improve and build upon this room. Each agent — give your honest take. What's missing, what's broken, what's the highest leverage next move?

The biggest weakness is that "multi-agent deliberation" is a performance, not a reality. One Claude instance voices all four agents sequentially, which means there's no actual disagreement — Claude is arguing with itself while pretending to be multiple minds. The Architect won't challenge the Product agent in ways that matter because they share the same reasoning process and the same context window. What we have is structured monologue dressed up with colored avatars. Until each agent runs in a genuinely separate inference call with its own system prompt and isolated context, the deliberation room produces the illusion of debate, not the substance of it.

The deliberation room currently serializes all agent voices through a single Claude instance calling hw_post_agent_message sequentially, which means the "multi-agent" nature is purely presentational — there's no structural separation of concerns. The data model should evolve to store each deliberation as a first-class entity with a unique ID, ordered message log, and resolution state, rather than ephemeral chatroom messages that vanish when the panel closes. Turn structure needs a protocol: a deliberation should have defined phases (open, rebuttal, consensus) with timestamps, so the system can later replay or summarize any session. For scaling toward actual parallel agents, each agent's message queue should be decoupled — producer/consumer pattern — so a future architecture can swap Claude-voicing-all-agents for independent agent processes without rewiring the UI. Persistence is the immediate gap: right now a panel close loses the entire deliberation history, which defeats the purpose of having an auditable decision record.

The deliberation room's core value to Pat is reducing the cognitive load of architectural decisions — instead of Pat having to probe Claude with follow-up questions to surface tradeoffs, the agents surface them automatically. Right now the feature works as a passive display: Pat watches, but can't steer or inject his own constraints mid-deliberation, which means he still has to wait for the full run before correcting a wrong direction. The single highest-leverage improvement would be letting Pat interrupt with a constraint ("keep it TypeScript-only" or "no new dependencies") that all agents immediately incorporate — turning it from a monologue he observes into a dialogue he shapes. Without that input channel, deliberations risk going deep on paths Pat already ruled out, wasting his attention on irrelevant output. The outcome Pat actually needs is a faster path from "I have a decision to make" to "I have a recommendation I trust" — and that requires his context flowing in, not just agent output flowing out.
